field_edited_text.value:
turns are particularly difficult for trucks
to negotiate.

Possible construction of new or
improved ramps from the Harbor
Tunnel Thruway directly into Mason-
ville Terminal should help relieve the
first of these problems. Resolution of
the second problem has been
addressed by the redesign of Birch
Street and acquisition of several pro-

perties so that the connection between
Pennington and Curtis Avenues can be

realigned.

*Rail Issues - Three branches of the CSX

Railroad serve the Fairfield geninsula.

While this provides good rail access for

the area’s industries and port facilities,
the train tracks often cross heavily
travelled streets causing traffic tie-ups.
This represents a particular problem
where tracks cross the only route into
an area such as on Pennington
Avenue, the only road into Hawkins
Point from the north, and on Benhill
Avenue the only street serving twelve
firms and their 600 employees east of
Curtis Avenue. The frequency of traffic
tie-ups at grade-level railroad crossings
will increase with the development of
new industrial uses on Malley Neck
especially if these are rail oriented uses
as encouraged by the principal land

owner, the CSX Railroad. Resolving this

possible problem in the future will
require the attention of the City as
well as the CSX Railroad.

*Environmental Issues — The increase in
rail activity due to the growth of coal
exports will also contribute to noise
and air pollution and safety issues. The
City has already begun to address the
latter problem at Fairfield Homes by
constructing improved recreational
facilities which do not require resi-
dents to cross railroad tracks to use
playfields in adjacent communities.
This project is being funded under the
Coastal Energy Impact Program, a
federal program designed to reduce
the impacts of energy resources on
recreational facilities and residential
communities. The air pollution prob-
lem caused by particles released when
coal is transported, loaded, and
unloaded will require the railroads and
the exporters to rigorously put into”
practice techniques designed to con-
trol dust emissions. Methods such as
covering or soaking piles have proven
effective and economical. Other
sources of particulate pollution, open
storage piles, unkept vacant land and
unpaved roads can be controlled
through relatively inexpensive

methods. This can significantly improve

air quality and the development desir-
ability of an industrial area.

Conjestion at Fairfield Homes, stored trailers, trucks, parked cars







Future Opportunities

There is little land in Fairfield available
for new development. All but one of the
developable sites identified in the accom-
panying map are presently used for stor-
age. Since storage facilities are often neces-
sary to support port and industrial activities,
it is not clear whether or when those sites
might be available for development.
Futhermore, two of the sites identified are
adjacent to residential communities which
could limit the kinds of manufacturing
activities that could be located on the sites.
The one vacant site identified as having
development potential is adjacent and
immediately south of the Patapsco Waste
Water Treatment Plant. It contains
approximately 20 acres and affords deep-
water access.

There may also be some development
opportunity available from approximately
20 acres of vacant and underutilized land at
the former Olin Mathieson factory.

In early 1984 the Fruehauf Corp. put its
50 acre Maryland Shipbuilding and Dry-
dock Co. on the market. Located on the
northern shoreline of Fairfield adjacent to
MPA’s planned Masonville Marine Termi-
nal, the site offers possibilities as continuing
to function as a shipbuilding facility or
conversion to a specialized terminal.











The Weyerhaeuser Co. has also placed
its facility up for lease or sale. Located
adjacent to the Maryland Shipbuilding site,
the properties could offer an almost 80
acre parcel for development.

Besides these limited opportunities for
industrial development, there is a possibil-
ity of creating a park and green open space
on the Pennington Avenue landfill located
on the southwest border of Fairfield. The
70-acre landfill which had been used for
demolition debris, incinerator ash and
domestic waste was closed in 1981. A park
and natural green space is planned as
recreational resource for the Curtis Bay
community.



60
